titles.title: Reauthorizing Security for Supreme Court Justices Act of 2019
Reauthorizing Security for Supreme Court Justices Act of 2019
Reauthorizing Security for Supreme Court Justices Act of 2019
Reauthorizing Security for Supreme Court Justices Act of 2019
Reauthorizing Security for Supreme Court Justices Act of 2019

To authorize the Marshal of the Supreme Court and the Supreme Court Police to protect the Justices, employees, and official guests of the Supreme Court outside of the Supreme Court grounds, and for other purposes.
Reauthorizing Security for Supreme Court Justices Act of 2019

action.text: Referred to the House Committee on the Judiciary.
Referred to the Subcommittee on Courts, Intellectual Property, and the Internet.
Subcommittee on Courts, Intellectual Property, and the Internet Discharged.
Committee Consideration and Mark-up Session Held.

calendar.text: Ordered to be Reported by Voice Vote.

action.text: Reported by the Committee on Judiciary. H. Rept. 116-278.

calendar.text: Placed on the Union Calendar, Calendar No. 223.

action.text: Mr. Stanton moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
DEBATE - The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 4258.

vote.text: On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.

action.text: Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
Received in the Senate, read twice.

vote.text: Passed Senate without amendment by Unanimous Consent.

action.text: Message on Senate action sent to the House.

committee.subcommittee: Courts, Intellectual Property, and the Internet
committee.name: House Judiciary

term.name: Government employee pay, benefits, personnel management

bill.summary:
Reauthorizing Security for Supreme Court Justices Act of 2019
This bill permanently authorizes the Marshal of the Supreme Court and the Supreme Court Police to provide security protection for Supreme Court Justices (and their official guests) and officers and employees of the Supreme Court.
Additionally, it permits such protection to be provided in any location—not just in any state.
